intro: Cassine lyciodes, commonly known as the swamp cassine, is a deciduous shrub native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Lythraceae and is characterized by its broad, ovate leaves and showy, pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in wetland habitats, such as swamps and along riverbanks, where it thrives in moist, acidic soils. Its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release small, winged seeds. Cassine lyciodes plays an important ecological role by providing habitat and food for various wildlife species.
